item.title: Problems | Project Lovelace
item.description: Welcome to Project Lovelace! We're still in early development so there are still tons of bugs to find and improvements to make. If you have any suggestions, complaints, or comments please let us know on Discourse, Discord, or GitHub!

item.title: 5G: The outsourced elephant in the room - Articles
item.description: In a break from the usual GPS/Galileo, DNA and C++ posts, here is a bit on 5G and national security. It turns out that through PowerDNS and its parent company Open-Xchange, we know a lot about how large scale European communication service providers work - most of whom are our customers in some way. In addition, in a previous life I worked in national security and because of that I have relevant knowledge of how governments (your own and foreign ones) “interact” with telecommunication providers.

item.title: Containers at the edge: it’s not what you think, or maybe it is

item.title: Content-aware image resizing in JavaScript | Trekhleb
item.description: JavaScript implementation of so-called Seam Carving algorithm for the content-aware image resizing and objects removal. Dynamic programming approach is applied to optimize the resizing time.

item.title: Application and package management using Helm - Learn
item.description: Helm is an application package manager for Kubernetes that you use to standardize and simplify the deployment of cloud-native applications on Kubernetes. Here you'll see how to install third-party packages called Helm charts and how to create and install Helm charts for the workloads your teams develop.

item.title: QUIC and HTTP/3 Support now in Firefox Nightly and Beta – Mozilla Hacks - the Web developer blog
item.description: Support for QUIC and HTTP/3 is now enabled by default in Firefox Nightly and Firefox Beta. HTTP/3 will be available by the end of May.

item.title: My Go Executable Files Are Still Getting Larger (What's New in 2021 and Go 1.16)
item.description: Two years ago, I wrote about how to utilize D3 and a tree map visualization to explore the size of executable files produced by the Go compiler. Sadly, the situation is even worse now than it was back in 2019.
